awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Twist on Muscle Contraction
awd_abstract_narration:
The sliding filament theory is widely accepted as a useful model of muscle contraction in isolated preparations. However, the theory fails to account for critically important characteristics of muscle function. Despite decades of work, a predictive model of muscle force during natural movements remains elusive. The researchers will test the hypothesis that important properties of muscle can be explained by the winding filament hypothesis. The proposed work has significant potential to inform our understanding of how neural activation and applied forces together determine in vivo muscle force. Results from the research will be integrated into graduate and/or undergraduate courses at Denison University (RUI-eligible), Northwestern University, and Northern Arizona University. In addition, the research team will leverage programs at Denison University and Northern Arizona University  for recruiting under-represented participants in research. Results will be disseminated to broad audiences through standard mechanisms of publication and diverse public media, as well as participation in interdisciplinary conferences in the areas of engineering, biomechanics, and physiology.

The researchers will use the mdm mouse to test predictions of the winding filament hypothesis. The winding hypothesis claims that, in addition to the thin filaments, titin is activated by Ca2+, and that cross-bridges not only translate but also rotate the thin filaments, storing elastic energy in PEVK titin during isometric force development. Due to constraints of sarcomere geometry on titin activation and winding, the hypothesis makes unique quantitative predictions about the effects of stimulation and length changes on muscle force. By including different muscles in the proposed studies, the researchers can determine whether naturally occurring variation in titin structure and function contributes to activation- and length-dependent muscle properties (e.g., doublet potentiation and force depression/enhancement). The experiments will test whether titin activation and winding, alone or in combination, can account for observed muscle forces by comparing experimental results to model predictions.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional models of muscle contraction have consistently failed to predict natural movements of humans and other animals. In the last ten years, it has become increasingly clear that an understanding of the underlying molecular mechanisms is necessary to advance our understanding of biomechanics and muscle physiology. The overall goal of this project was to investigate the role of the elastic muscle protein, titin in active muscle with the purpose of improving current predictive models. Several recent studies have provided evidence that titin is a tunable spring in muscle. Here, we test the hypothesis that titin binds to actin in the presence of calcium which increases titin and whole muscle stiffness. Monroy?s role in this project was to conduct ex vivo muscle experiments that could be used to validate and test novel muscle models with titin developed by Sandercock and Nishikawa. Using the mdm mouse, with a small deletion to the N2A region of titin, we compared active and passive stiffness and muscle force in wild type and mdm muscles subjected to different activation and length changes. Results show that muscle stiffness increases with activation in wild type but not mdm muscles. In addition, when a single stimulus (i.e. doublet) is added shortly after the onset of a train of stimuli, peak muscle force and the rate of force development nearly double but these effects are reduced or absent in mdm muscles. When doublet stimulation is applied during a stretch-shortening cycle, peak muscle force increases, and the work of a muscle can increase by more than 50% per cycle. The effect of a doublet depends on the phase of activation relative to length changes and thus, can convert a muscle from a motor into a brake. These experiments support the hypothesis that N2A titin binds to actin when calcium is present, which decreases titin?s free length and increases titin and muscle stiffness. A titin-based muscle model performs relatively well at predicting the effects of doublet potentiation as well many other muscle properties that have eluded conventional muscle models. This work has the potential to fill in gaps in our understanding of muscle physiology and movement. At the Claremont Colleges, the project contributed to six completed undergraduate senior theses, and provided interdisciplinary research experiences for three additional undergraduate students.
